text: In a hybrid warehouse automation in retail where stakeholders keep adding requests and governance requires scope control, what should the project manager do to break down scope into workable components?

options.label: decompose deliverables into manageable work packages or stories
leave scope at high-level themes only
assign tasks without clarifying deliverables
skip backlog refinement to save time

explanation: Option a is correct because breakdown clarifies work and ownership. Option b is incorrect because vague scope hampers planning and control. Option c is incorrect because unclear deliverables cause rework. Option d is incorrect because unrefined backlog slows delivery.

text: Given a predictive warehouse automation in insurance where dependencies to other programs exist and a demo to regulators is pending, which action best supports break down scope into workable components?

options.label: let vendors define scope alone
split epics into thin vertical slices with acceptance criteria
ignore dependencies when breaking down work
leave scope at high-level themes only

explanation: Option b is correct because small slices enable incremental delivery. Option a is incorrect because lack of oversight risks misalignment. Option c is incorrect because missing dependencies creates surprises. Option d is incorrect because vague scope hampers planning and control.

text: While facing a hybrid omnichannel launch in insurance where dependencies to other programs exist and a demo to regulators is pending, what is the most effective next step to break down scope into workable components?

options.label: assign tasks without clarifying deliverables
skip backlog refinement to save time
involve the team to size and understand the pieces
let vendors define scope alone

explanation: Option c is correct because team input improves estimates and buy-in. Option a is incorrect because unclear deliverables cause rework. Option b is incorrect because unrefined backlog slows delivery. Option d is incorrect because lack of oversight risks misalignment.

text: For a product-led omnichannel launch in logistics where stakeholders keep adding requests and budget pressure is high, what should the project manager do first to break down scope into workable components?

options.label: ignore dependencies when breaking down work
leave scope at high-level themes only
assign tasks without clarifying deliverables
maintain traceability from breakdown items to requirements

explanation: Option d is correct because traceability ensures coverage. Option a is incorrect because missing dependencies creates surprises. Option b is incorrect because vague scope hampers planning and control. Option c is incorrect because unclear deliverables cause rework.
